content: [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland")'s [Defence Forces](/wiki/Defence_Forces_(Ireland) "Defence Forces (Ireland)") (Óglaigh na hÉireann) were formed within the Irish Free State by the unification of the [Irish Army](/wiki/Irish_Army "Irish Army"), the [Irish Naval Service](/wiki/Irish_Naval_Service "Irish Naval Service"), the [Irish Air Corps](/wiki/Irish_Air_Corps "Irish Air Corps") and the [Reserve Defence Forces](/wiki/Reserve_Defence_Forces "Reserve Defence Forces").
sources: ["Defence Forces History: History of the Army"](https://www.military.ie/en/public-information/defence-forces-museums/defence-forces-history/history-of-the-army/history-of-the-army.html). [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20200427081616/https://www.military.ie/en/public-information/defence-forces-museums/defence-forces-history/history-of-the-army/history-of-the-army.html) from the original on 27 April 2020. Retrieved 10 February 2020.

content: [Stanley Baldwin](/wiki/Stanley_Baldwin "Stanley Baldwin")'s [Conservative Party](/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK) "Conservative Party (UK)") tabled a [motion of censure](/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence "Motion of no confidence") against Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald "Ramsay MacDonald") and his [Labour](/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)") government over its handling of the [Campbell Case](/wiki/Campbell_Case "Campbell Case"). The UK [Liberal Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_(UK) "Liberal Party (UK)") broke from its coalition with [Labour](/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)") and announced that the Liberals would not vote to ratify the treaties that the UK had signed with the Soviet Union.
sources: Dobson, Jeremy (2009). *Why Do the People Hate Me So?: The Strange Interlude Between the Two Great Wars in the Britain of Stanley Baldwin*. [Leicester](/wiki/Leicester "Leicester"): Troubador Publishing Ltd. p. 103. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1848762-398](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1848762-398 "Special:BookSources/978-1848762-398").
Steele, John (October 2, 1924). "Liberals Issue Ultimatum to English Labor". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 11.

content: Baseball commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis "Kenesaw Mountain Landis") banned [New York Giants](/wiki/History_of_the_New_York_Giants_(NL) "History of the New York Giants (NL)") player [Jimmy O'Connell](/wiki/Jimmy_O%27Connell_(baseball) "Jimmy O'Connell (baseball)") and coach [Cozy Dolan](/wiki/Cozy_Dolan_(1910s_outfielder) "Cozy Dolan (1910s outfielder)") over a bribery scandal. They were charged with offering [Philadelphia Phillies](/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia Phillies") shortstop [Heinie Sand](/wiki/Heinie_Sand "Heinie Sand") $500 to [throw](/wiki/Match_fixing "Match fixing") a game on September 27 to help the Giants win the [National League](/wiki/National_League_(baseball) "National League (baseball)") pennant.
sources: ["Bribe Scandal Hits Giants on Eve of Series"](https://www.newspapers.com/image/354936930/). *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 2, 1924. p. 1. Retrieved February 24, 2022 – via [Newspapers.com](/wiki/Newspapers.com "Newspapers.com").

content: The [Geneva Protocol for the Pacific Settlement of International Disputes](/wiki/Geneva_Protocol_(1924) "Geneva Protocol (1924)") received preliminary approval at the [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations"). The agreement required formal approval to be given by all governments concerned, and was understood to have little meaning until the conclusion of the world disarmament conference was concluded the next year. The Protocol included a very controversial piece of wording added at the insistence of Japan, which allowed for the restriction of immigration to become a matter of international jurisdiction if it endangered the peace.
sources: Sheean, Vincent (October 3, 1924). "League Adopts Arbitration by Japanese Rule". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. pp. 1–2.
Bennett, James O'Donnell (October 5, 1924). "Hands Off U.S.! – Coolidge". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*: 1–2.

Burkman, Thomas W. (2008). *Japan and the League of Nations: Empire and World Order, 1914–1938*. University of Hawai'i Press. pp. 119–122. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-8248-2982-7](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-2982-7 "Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-2982-7").

content: [Cesáreo Onzari](/wiki/Ces%C3%A1reo_Onzari "Cesáreo Onzari") of the [Argentina national football team](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national football team") scored the first goal from a [corner kick](/wiki/Corner_kick "Corner kick") in international play after the rules of soccer football had been amended on June 14 by the [International Football Association Board](/wiki/International_Football_Association_Board "International Football Association Board"). The first goal in a professional league game had come on August 23. Onzri's goal came against [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football team"), which had recently won the [1924 Olympic title](/wiki/Football_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1924 Summer Olympics"). For this reason the direct goal from a corner kick is called an *Olympic goal* or *gol olímpico* in Latin America.
sources: Barnade, Oscar (October 2004). ["El gol olímpico cumple 80"](http://www.clarin.com/deportes/fundador-gol-olimpico_0_1066093752.html). *[Clarín](/wiki/Clar%C3%ADn_(Argentine_newspaper) "Clarín (Argentine newspaper)")* (in Spanish). Retrieved 17 November 2009.

Barnade, Oscar (October 2004). ["El gol olímpico cumple 80"](http://www.clarin.com/deportes/fundador-gol-olimpico_0_1066093752.html). *[Clarín](/wiki/Clar%C3%ADn_(Argentine_newspaper) "Clarín (Argentine newspaper)")* (in Spanish). Retrieved 17 November 2009.

Barnade, Oscar (October 2004). ["El gol olímpico cumple 80"](http://www.clarin.com/deportes/fundador-gol-olimpico_0_1066093752.html). *[Clarín](/wiki/Clar%C3%ADn_(Argentine_newspaper) "Clarín (Argentine newspaper)")* (in Spanish). Retrieved 17 November 2009.

content: Baseball commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis "Kenesaw Mountain Landis") said the [World Series](/wiki/1924_World_Series "1924 World Series") would go forward despite the bribery scandal. "Inside of four days after the attempted bribery of [Sand](/wiki/Heinie_Sand "Heinie Sand") of the [Phillies](/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia Phillies") had occurred, the guilty persons had been placed on baseball's ineligible list. Surely our speedy action in the matter must indicate that the game is being kept clean", he said.
sources: Vaughan, Irving (October 3, 1924). "'Won't Stop Series' – Landis". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: **Died:** [William B. Ross](/wiki/William_B._Ross "William B. Ross"), 50, [Governor of Wyoming](/wiki/List_of_governors_of_Wyoming "List of governors of Wyoming") since 1923, died of complications from an appendectomy he had undergone one week earlier. He was temporarily succeeded by Secretary of State [Frank Lucas](/wiki/Frank_Lucas_(Wyoming_politician) "Frank Lucas (Wyoming politician)") pending a special election  Governor Ross's widow, [Nellie Tayloe Ross](/wiki/Nellie_Tayloe_Ross "Nellie Tayloe Ross"), run in the election and win the governorship.
sources: ["Gov. W. B. Ross Answers Call"](https://www.newspapers.com/clip/42001177/casper_startribune/). *Casper Star-Tribune*. 2 October 1924. p. 4. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20200110010901/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/42001177/casper_startribune/) from the original on 10 January 2020 – via [Newspapers.com](/wiki/Newspapers.com "Newspapers.com").

content: Britain's *[Evening Standard](/wiki/London_Evening_Standard "London Evening Standard")* blasted the [Geneva Protocol](/wiki/Geneva_Protocol_(1924) "Geneva Protocol (1924)") and called on Australia, Canada and New Zealand to quit the [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations") over it, pointing out that if Australia refused to submit to Japan's demand that it alter its immigration policy, the British fleet might be called upon to impose a naval [blockade](/wiki/Blockade "Blockade") in the name of the League.
sources: Steele, John (October 4, 1924). "Dominions of Britain Urged to Quit League". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 7.

content: A conference in London between the United Kingdom and [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt") on the issue of Egyptian independence ended without success.
sources: Steele, John (October 4, 1924). "London Rejects Egyptian Plan for Self Rule". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 7.

content: A feud erupted between major league baseball commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis "Kenesaw Mountain Landis") and [American League](/wiki/American_League "American League") president [Ban Johnson](/wiki/Ban_Johnson "Ban Johnson"). Johnson told the media that he would pursue an independent investigation of the circumstances under which the [New York Giants](/wiki/History_of_the_New_York_Giants_(NL) "History of the New York Giants (NL)") won the pennant, and that they should be forbidden from playing in the World Series. Johnson called Landis a "wild-eyed, crazy nut" who was "protecting the crooks" by failing to investigate the scandal more thoroughly.
sources: Robertson, H.H. (October 4, 1924). "Ban Johnson after M'Graw and Stoneham". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. pp. 1, 13.

content: In the [Second Zhili–Fengtian War](/wiki/Second_Zhili%E2%80%93Fengtian_War "Second Zhili–Fengtian War"), [Zhang Zuolin](/wiki/Zhang_Zuolin "Zhang Zuolin") won a major victory at [Fengtian](/wiki/Liaoning "Liaoning").
sources: Matheson, Roderick (October 6, 1924). "Peking's Army Ruoted; 10,000 Men Captured". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: The [First Division Monument](/wiki/First_Division_Monument "First Division Monument") was dedicated in Washington, D.C. During his dedication speech, U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge") briefly commenting on the [Geneva Protocol](/wiki/Geneva_Protocol_(1924) "Geneva Protocol (1924)"), saying, "We do not propose to entrust to any other power or combination of powers any authority to make up our minds for us."
sources: [Bennett, James O'Donnell](/wiki/James_O%27Donnell_Bennett "James O'Donnell Bennett") (October 5, 1924). "Hands Off U.S.! – Coolidge". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: **Died:** [Burt E. Skeel](/wiki/Burt_E._Skeel "Burt E. Skeel"), 30, American racing pilot, was killed while competing in the [Pulitzer Trophy Race](/wiki/National_Air_Races "National Air Races") at [Wilbur Wright Field](/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base") in [Dayton, Ohio](/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio "Dayton, Ohio"). Skeel's Curtiss Aircraft flyer lost both wings as he was traveling at high speed at an atltitude of 2,000 feet (610 m).
sources: "Capt. Skeel Killed in Dayton Air Race; 50,000 See Plunge; Plane Crumples as Army Officer Dives for Start in Pulitzer Prize Contest". *The New York Times*. October 5, 1924. p. 1.

content: A harsh ordinance was issued in [British India](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") aimed at suppressing "terrorists". Pro-independence nationalists such as [Subhas Chandra Bose](/wiki/Subhas_Chandra_Bose "Subhas Chandra Bose") would be arrested under the new law.
sources: Sengupta, Nitish K. (2011). *Land of Two Rivers: A History of Bengal from the Mahabharata to Mujib*. London: Penguin Books. p. 343. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [9780143416784](/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780143416784 "Special:BookSources/9780143416784").

content: [Carlos José Solórzano](/wiki/Carlos_Jos%C3%A9_Sol%C3%B3rzano "Carlos José Solórzano") was [elected](/wiki/1924_Nicaraguan_general_election "1924 Nicaraguan general election") to be [President of Nicaragua](/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Nicaragua "List of Presidents of Nicaragua"), to take office on January 1. He would be overthrown on March 14, 1926.
sources: ["Gobernantes de Nicaragua"](https://web.archive.org/web/20121009181920/http://www.mined.gob.ni/gobern31.php) (in Spanish). Ministerio de Educación. 9 December 2012. Archived from [the original](http://www.mined.gob.ni/gobern31.php) on 9 October 2012.

content: Seven people died and 48 were injured during rioting in [Camagüey](/wiki/Camag%C3%BCey "Camagüey"), [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"), during a political rally for presidential candidate Mario Menocal ahead of the country's [general election](/wiki/1924_Cuban_general_election "1924 Cuban general election").
sources: "7 Die, 48 Hurt in Rioting During Cuban Campaign". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 6, 1924. p. 6.

[Radio Marconi](/wiki/Rai_Radio_1 "Rai Radio 1"), the first radio station in [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy") for the general public, began broadcasting from [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome") as a service of [Unione radiofonica italiana](/wiki/Unione_radiofonica_italiana "Unione radiofonica italiana") (URI). The station, with call sign 1-RO, transmitted at the 425 metre wavelength, equivalent to the 710 AM radio frequency. At 9:00 in the evening, Maria Luisa Boncompagni read an announcement that the first program would be an "inaugural symphony concert", followed by an introduction by Ines Viviani Donarelli that she and three other members of a string quartet would perform [Joseph Haydn](/wiki/Joseph_Haydn "Joseph Haydn")'s [Opus 7](/wiki/List_of_compositions_by_Joseph_Haydn#String_Quartets "List of compositions by Joseph Haydn").
sources: ["Storia della Radio dal 1924 al 1933"](http://www.storiadellaradio.rai.it/dl/portali/site/articolo/ContentItem-d3384361-91fc-4b38-b8ab-9ec4031ec7aa.html). *Storia della radio* (in Italian). Rai. Retrieved 26 September 2019.

content: [Ali of Hejaz](/wiki/Ali_of_Hejaz "Ali of Hejaz") was proclaimed the new [King of Hejaz](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz "Kingdom of Hejaz") after his father, [King Hussein bin Ali](/wiki/Hussein_bin_Ali,_King_of_Hejaz "Hussein bin Ali, King of Hejaz") fled from [Mecca](/wiki/Mecca "Mecca") to [Jeddah](/wiki/Jeddah "Jeddah") to avoid the [conquest of Nejd](/wiki/Unification_of_Saudi_Arabia "Unification of Saudi Arabia") by the neighboring [Sultanate of Nejd](/wiki/Sultanate_of_Nejd "Sultanate of Nejd"), led by [Ibn Saud](/wiki/Ibn_Saud "Ibn Saud").
sources: ["Kingdom of Nadj-Hijaz (1916-1932)"](http://uca.edu/politicalscience/dadm-project/middle-eastnorth-africapersian-gulf-region/kingdom-of-nadj-hijaz-1916-1932/). *[University of Central Arkansas](/wiki/University_of_Central_Arkansas "University of Central Arkansas")*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The classic German silent film *[Das Wachsfigurenkabinett](/wiki/Waxworks_(film) "Waxworks (film)")* (*Waxworks*), directed by [Paul Leni](/wiki/Paul_Leni "Paul Leni"), premiered in Austria.
sources: ["Silent Era : Home Video Reviews"](https://www.silentera.com/video/waxworksHV.html#targetText=Release%20date%3A%2024%20September%202002.&targetText=Kino%20International%20scored%20a%20big,much%2Dliked%20Paul%20Leni%20film). *Silent Era*. 24 September 2002. Retrieved 31 August 2021.

The British [Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)") ruled out affiliation with the [Communist Party](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain "Communist Party of Great Britain") by a card vote of 3,185,000 to 193,000 at Labour's national congress in London. "Communism is nothing practical. It is a product of [czarism](/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia "Tsardom of Russia") and war betrayal, and as such we will have nothing to do with it", Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald "Ramsay MacDonald") said.
sources: Steele, John (October 8, 1924). "British Labor Refuses to Let Communists In". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 11.

content: The Soviet Union's Council of People's Commissars, the [Sovnarkom](/wiki/Sovnarkom "Sovnarkom"), declared an amnesty to all participants of the recent [August Uprising](/wiki/August_Uprising "August Uprising") against the [Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Georgian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic") on the condition that they surrender their weapons voluntarily.
sources: [Lang, David Marshall](/wiki/David_Marshall_Lang "David Marshall Lang") (1962). *A Modern History of Georgia*. [Weidenfeld and Nicolson](/wiki/Weidenfeld_and_Nicolson "Weidenfeld and Nicolson"). p. 243.

content: The United States [accepted diplomatic relations](/wiki/Ireland%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Ireland–United States relations") with the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State"), separately from the United Kingdom, as [Timothy Smiddy](/wiki/Timothy_Smiddy "Timothy Smiddy") was accepted by the U.S. as Minister Plenipotentiary from Ireland, with an office in [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."). The U.S. would not send a diplomat to Ireland until 1927.
sources: ["A Guide to the United States' History of Recognition, Diplomatic, and Consular Relations, by Country, since 1776: Ireland"](https://history.state.gov/countries/ireland). [U.S. Department of State](/wiki/U.S._Department_of_State "U.S. Department of State") [Office of the Historian](/wiki/Office_of_the_Historian "Office of the Historian").
["Chiefs of Mission for Ireland"](https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/people/chiefsofmission/ireland). *history.state.gov*. Retrieved April 18, 2017.

content: [Ramsay MacDonald](/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald "Ramsay MacDonald") and his [Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)") were defeated in the [House of Commons](/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom "House of Commons of the United Kingdom") by a vote of 364 to 198, on a vote of censure over the government's handling of the [Campbell Case](/wiki/Campbell_Case "Campbell Case").
sources: Steele, John (October 9, 1924). "Commons Votes Out Labor". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: In the UK, King [George V](/wiki/George_V "George V") dissolved parliament at the request of Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald "Ramsay MacDonald"), and scheduled new elections for the House of Commons for October 29.
sources: ["Early Election"](http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NA19241010.2.40). *[The Northern Advocate](/wiki/The_Northern_Advocate "The Northern Advocate")*. [Whangarei](/wiki/Whangarei "Whangarei"). October 10, 1924. p. 5.

content: [Soldier Field](/wiki/Soldier_Field "Soldier Field"), a stadium with 60,000 seats, was dedicated in [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), as Grant Park Stadium. The stadium, which would become home to the NFL's [Chicago Bears](/wiki/Chicago_Bears "Chicago Bears"), would be renamed Soldier Field on [Veterans Day](/wiki/Veterans_Day "Veterans Day") in 1925.
sources: ["60,000 Voice City's Spirit at Stadium Fete"](https://www.newspapers.com/article/chicago-tribune-60000-voice-citys-spir/69950747/). *Chicago Tribune*. October 10, 1924. p. 5 – via Newspapers.com.

content: **Died:** [Jake Daubert](/wiki/Jake_Daubert "Jake Daubert"), 40, American baseball player, 1913 National League Most Valuable Player, died of surgical complications from an appendectomy after avoiding surgery in order to play in the Cincinnati Reds' final home game.
sources: ["The Obit for Jake Daubert"](https://web.archive.org/web/20061113003614/http://www.thedeadballera.com/Obits/Daubert.Jake.Obit.html). *TheDeadBallEra.com*. Archived from [the original](http://www.thedeadballera.com/Obits/Daubert.Jake.Obit.html) on November 13, 2006. Retrieved November 10, 2006.

content: [Walter Johnson](/wiki/Walter_Johnson "Walter Johnson") pitched four shutout innings of relief as the [Washington Senators](/wiki/History_of_the_Washington_Senators_(1901%E2%80%9360) "History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)") beat the [New York Giants](/wiki/History_of_the_New_York_Giants_(NL) "History of the New York Giants (NL)"), 4 to 3, in 12 innings to win the [World Series](/wiki/1924_World_Series "1924 World Series") in a winner-take-all Game 7. This game is considered by some sports historians to be one of the greatest baseball games ever played and the conclusion of one of the most exciting World Series of all time.
sources: Wilbert, Warren N. (2004). *The Greatest World Series Games: Baseball Historians Choose 26 Classics*. [McFarland & Company](/wiki/McFarland_%26_Company "McFarland & Company"). p. 34. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [9780786418237](/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780786418237 "Special:BookSources/9780786418237").

content: The Commonwealth Electoral Act made [compulsory voting](/wiki/Compulsory_voting "Compulsory voting") the law in Australia.
sources: ["Commonwealth Electoral Act 1924"](http://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/item-sdid-89.html). *Museum of Australia Democracy*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The [Office of the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Foreign,_Commonwealth_and_Development_Office "Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office") in the United Kingdom received the fabricated [Zinoviev letter](/wiki/Zinoviev_letter "Zinoviev letter"), purporting to be a directive from the Soviet Union's director of [Comintern](/wiki/Communist_International "Communist International") to order the [Communist Party of Great Britain](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain "Communist Party of Great Britain") to undermine the British government. The letter came two days after the vote of no confidence against Prime Minister MacDonald and was leaked by Conservative Party members within the Foreign Office to the local news media, including the *[Daily Mail](/wiki/Daily_Mail "Daily Mail")* newspaper, in advance of the elections set for October 29.
sources: Chester, Lewis; Fay, Stephen; Young, Hugo (1968). *The Zinoviev Letter*. [J.B. Lippincott](/wiki/J.B._Lippincott "J.B. Lippincott"). p. 65.

The [H. J. Heinz Company](/wiki/H._J._Heinz_Company "H. J. Heinz Company") celebrated its fifty-fifth birthday with banquets in different American cities. President [Calvin Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge") used the occasion to make a radio address from the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House") about business that was carried in 70 cities.
sources: "U.S. Fair to Fair Business, View of President". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 12, 1924. p. 3.

content: Baseball commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis "Kenesaw Mountain Landis") made his first public response to [Ban Johnson](/wiki/Ban_Johnson "Ban Johnson")'s criticisms of his handling of the recent bribery scandal, saying, "Answer Johnson? I don't have to... it has been done by the President of the United States." [Calvin Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge"), who attended three of the games played in Washington, said that "The contests which I witnessed maintained throughout a high degree of skill and every evidence of a high class of sportsmanship that will bring to every observer an increased respect for and confidence in our national game."
sources: "Landis Finally Takes Fling at Ban B. Johnson". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 12, 1924. p. 25.

content: The holy city of [Mecca](/wiki/Mecca "Mecca") was captured by the [Wahhabi Muslims](/wiki/Wahhabism "Wahhabism") in the [Saudi conquest of Hejaz](/wiki/Saudi_conquest_of_Hejaz "Saudi conquest of Hejaz") by the Saudi kingdom of [Nejd](/wiki/Nejd "Nejd").
sources: ["Chronology 1924"](http://www.indiana.edu/~league/1924.htm). *indiana.edu*. 2002. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The [National Hockey League](/wiki/1924%E2%80%9325_NHL_season "1924–25 NHL season"), which consisted solely of Canadian teams for its first seven seasons, became international for the first time with the addition of an American team. [Charles Adams](/wiki/Charles_Adams_(ice_hockey) "Charles Adams (ice hockey)"), a U.S. businessman and owner of a chain of grocery stores]] purchased one of the NHL's first two expansion franchises for $15,000 (equivalent to $269,000 in 2024  and named his team the [Boston Bruins](/wiki/History_of_the_Boston_Bruins "History of the Boston Bruins").
sources: Hockey Hall of Fame. ["Builder Inductees: Charles Adams"](http://www.legendsofhockey.net/LegendsOfHockey/jsp/LegendsMember.jsp?mem=b196001&type=Builder&page=bio&list=ByName#photo). *Legends of Hockey*.

content: [Henry Ford](/wiki/Henry_Ford "Henry Ford") withdrew his long-stalled bid to buy the nitrate works and dam at [Muscle Shoals, Alabama](/wiki/Muscle_Shoals,_Alabama "Muscle Shoals, Alabama").
sources: "Ford's Muscle Shoals Bid Off". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 14, 1924. p. 1.

content: '*Born:*[Roberto Viola](/wiki/Roberto_Eduardo_Viola "Roberto Eduardo Viola"), [President of Argentina](/wiki/President_of_Argentina "President of Argentina") during 1981, later imprisoned for seven years for human rights violations committed during Argentina's [Dirty War](/wiki/Dirty_War "Dirty War"); in [Buenos Aires](/wiki/Buenos_Aires "Buenos Aires") (d. 1994)
sources: ["Viola"](http://www.cairomontenotte.com/cognome/viola.html).

content: The [Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Tajik_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic"), which would later become the independent nation of [Tajikistan](/wiki/Tajikistan "Tajikistan"), was created as a partially self-governing entity with the new [Uzbek SSR](/wiki/Uzbek_SSR "Uzbek SSR") in the Soviet Union. It would become the Tadzhik Soviet Socialist Republic and one of the constituent republics of the Soviet Union on December 5, 1929, and become independent upon the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991.
sources: Ubiria, Grigol (2015). *Soviet Nation-Building in Central Asia: The Making of the Kazakh and Uzbek Nations*. [Taylor & Francis](/wiki/Taylor_%26_Francis "Taylor & Francis").

content: [Hjalmar Branting](/wiki/Hjalmar_Branting "Hjalmar Branting") formed a government as the new [Prime Minister of Sweden](/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Sweden "List of prime ministers of Sweden") after the resignation of [Ernst Trygger](/wiki/Ernst_Trygger "Ernst Trygger"), whose coalition government had lost power in the [September elections for the Riksdag](/wiki/1924_Swedish_general_election "1924 Swedish general election"). Terminally ill, Branting would serve for less than three months before resigning in favor of Commerce and Industry Minister [Rickard Sandler](/wiki/Rickard_Sandler "Rickard Sandler").

	* [Michel Mirowski](/wiki/Michel_Mirowski "Michel Mirowski") (Mordechai Frydman), Polish-born Israeli physician and inventor of the [implantable cardioverter-defibrillator](/wiki/Implantable_cardioverter-defibrillator "Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator") (ICD); in [Warsaw](/wiki/Warsaw "Warsaw") (died of [multiple myeloma](/wiki/Multiple_myeloma "Multiple myeloma"), 1990)
	* [John E. Corbally](/wiki/John_E._Corbally "John E. Corbally"), American academic administrator who served President of the [University of Illinois system](/wiki/University_of_Illinois_system "University of Illinois system"), 1971 to 1979, before becoming the first President of the [John D. and Catherine T. content: In [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler"), incarcerated for organizing the 1923 attempt to overthrow the [Weimar Republic](/wiki/Weimar_Republic "Weimar Republic") government, had a statement printed admitting that he was born in the Austro-Hungarian Empire rather than in Germany. Hitler, who was facing deportation back to Austria, argued that he had lost his Austrian citizenship after volunteering to serve in the German Army during World War I and said that "I never felt as an Austrian citizen but always as a German only... It was this mentality that made me draw the ultimate conclusion and do military service in the German Army. Hitler would not renounce his Austrian citizenship until April 7, 1925, and would not become a citizen of Germany until 1932 upon his appointment as a state government official.
sources: Hamann, Brigitte (2010). *Hitler's Vienna: A Portrait of the Tyrant as a Young Man*. Tauris Parke. p. 402. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-84885-277-8](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84885-277-8 "Special:BookSources/978-1-84885-277-8").

The first "round-the-world" wireless radio communication took place between locations in [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand") and the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") as favorable atmospheric conditions permitted amateur [ham radio](/wiki/Ham_radio "Ham radio") operators to hear each other over a distance of more than 19,000 kilometres (12,000 mi). Amateurs in both countries heard signals the night before. Transmitting on the 80-metre short wave band from New Zealand, at Waiheua near [Dunedin](/wiki/Dunedin "Dunedin"), New Zealand, telegraphed the message, in [Morse code](/wiki/Morse_code "Morse code"), "Z4AA calling. Pass the following to Radio Society of Great Britain. Greetings from New Zealand. Z4AA calling. Pass following to G2OD. Your signals strong last night." Mr. E. J. Simmonds of [Gerrards Cross](/wiki/Gerrards_Cross "Gerrards Cross"), [Buckinghamshire](/wiki/Buckinghamshire "Buckinghamshire") in [England](/wiki/England "England"), operator of G2OD, acknowledged the call from Z4AA and asked for confirmation by [cable](/wiki/Radiogram_(message) "Radiogram (message)"). A little more than five hours later, he was handed a message from Dell that said, "Congratulations on first trans-world message. Dell. Waiheua, Dunedin, New Zealand." Later in the day, Cecil W. Goyder of [Hendon](/wiki/Hendon "Hendon"), near [London](/wiki/London "London") exchanged messages with Mr. Bell "for over an hour."
sources: ["Trans-World Radio. London and New Zealand Communicate"](https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-observer-the-first-ham-radio-transmi/140509632/). *The Observer*. London. October 20, 1924. p. 19 – via Newspapers.com.
"Wireless Talk over 10,000 Miles of Space— Communication between London and New Zealand". *Birmingham (England) Post*. October 20, 1924. p. 7.

content: In one of the most anticipated games of the [1924 college football season](/wiki/1924_college_football_season "1924 college football season"), played before 60,000 at the [Polo Grounds](/wiki/Polo_Grounds "Polo Grounds") stadium in New York City, [Notre Dame](/wiki/1924_Notre_Dame_Fighting_Irish_football_team "1924 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team") defeated [Army](/wiki/1924_Army_Cadets_football_team "1924 Army Cadets football team"), 13 to 7. That evening, nationally syndicated sportswriter [Grantland Rice](/wiki/Grantland_Rice "Grantland Rice") wrote his famous "Four Horsemen" column that was published in the next day's newspapers.
sources: "Notre Dame Eleven Defeats Army, 13-7; 60,000 Attend Big Game". *[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")*. October 19, 1924. p. 4.

content: The [1924 Cuba hurricane](/wiki/1924_Cuba_hurricane "1924 Cuba hurricane"), the earliest officially classified [Category 5 Atlantic hurricane](/wiki/List_of_Category_5_Atlantic_hurricanes "List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes"), struck western [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba") in [Pinar del Río Province](/wiki/Pinar_del_R%C3%ADo_Province "Pinar del Río Province") and killed 90 people.

content: The day after [Notre Dame](/wiki/1924_Notre_Dame_Fighting_Irish_football_team "1924 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team")'s defeat of Army in football, sportswriter [Grantland Rice](/wiki/Grantland_Rice "Grantland Rice")'s famous newspaper account was published nationwide. "Outlined against a blue-gray October sky," Rice wrote, "the [Four Horsemen](/wiki/Four_Horsemen_of_the_Apocalypse "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse") rode again. In dramatic lore they are known as [famine](/wiki/Famine "Famine"), [pestilence](/wiki/Infectious_disease "Infectious disease"), [destruction](/wiki/Global_catastrophic_risk "Global catastrophic risk") and [death](/wiki/Death "Death"). These are only aliases. Their real names are: [Stuhldreher](/wiki/Harry_Stuhldreher "Harry Stuhldreher"), [Miller](/wiki/Don_Miller_(American_football,_born_1902) "Don Miller (American football, born 1902)"), [Crowley](/wiki/Jim_Crowley "Jim Crowley") and [Layden](/wiki/Elmer_Layden "Elmer Layden")."

content: The [Hilldale Club](/wiki/Hilldale_Club "Hilldale Club") (near [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia")) of the [Eastern Colored League](/wiki/Eastern_Colored_League "Eastern Colored League") (ECL) defeated the [Kansas City Monarchs](/wiki/Kansas_City_Monarchs "Kansas City Monarchs") of the [Negro National League](/wiki/Negro_National_League_(1920%E2%80%931931) "Negro National League (1920–1931)"), 5 to 0, to win the championship baseball game of the best-5-of-9 [Colored World Series](/wiki/1924_Colored_World_Series "1924 Colored World Series"), five games to four.

German President [Friedrich Ebert](/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert "Friedrich Ebert") dissolved the [Reichstag](/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic) "Reichstag (Weimar Republic)") and called for new elections on December 7. The cabinet of Chancellor [Wilhelm Marx](/wiki/Wilhelm_Marx "Wilhelm Marx") fell apart after he granted three seats to nationalist parties in exchange for their voting to ratify the [Dawes Plan](/wiki/Dawes_Plan "Dawes Plan"), and the various factions were unable to cooperate afterward.
sources: [Seldes, George](/wiki/George_Seldes "George Seldes") (October 21, 1924). "Cabinet Crisis Hurls Germany into Election". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 3.

content: An explosion of gunpowder killed 14 servicemen on the U.S. Navy light cruiser [USS *Trenton*](/wiki/USS_Trenton_(CL-11) "USS Trenton (CL-11)") as it was conducting gunnery drills off the [Virginia Capes](/wiki/Virginia_Capes "Virginia Capes").
sources: "Explosion on Cruiser Kills 5 at Target Drill". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 21, 1924. p. 1.

["Casualties: US Navy and Marine Corps Personnel Killed and Injured in Selected Accidents and Other Incidents Not Directly the Result of Enemy Action"](http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/NHC/accidents.htm). *[ibiblio](/wiki/Ibiblio "Ibiblio")*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: In central Africa, the former German colony of [Ruanda-Urundi](/wiki/Ruanda-Urundi "Ruanda-Urundi") became [League of Nations mandate](/wiki/League_of_Nations_mandate "League of Nations mandate") territory under the administration of [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium "Belgium"), which controlled the neighboring colony of the [Belgian Congo](/wiki/Belgian_Congo "Belgian Congo"). With a capital at [Usumbura](/wiki/Bujumbura "Bujumbura") (now Bujumbura in Burundi), the mandate would later be divided into the nations of [Rwanda](/wiki/Rwanda "Rwanda") (speakers of the [Kinyarwanda](/wiki/Kinyarwanda "Kinyarwanda") Bantu dialect) and [Burundi](/wiki/Burundi "Burundi") (speakers of the [Kirundi](/wiki/Kirundi "Kirundi") Bantu dialect).
sources: Weinstein, Warren; Robert Schrere (1976). *Political Conflict and Ethnic Strategies: A Case Study of Burundi*. Syracuse University: Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs. p. 5. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [0-915984-20-2](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-915984-20-2 "Special:BookSources/0-915984-20-2").

content: The [National Association of Schools of Music](/wiki/National_Association_of_Schools_of_Music "National Association of Schools of Music") (NASM) was founded by leaders from six American music schools at a convention in [Pittsburgh](/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh").

[Elections were held](/wiki/1924_Norwegian_parliamentary_election "1924 Norwegian parliamentary election") for the 150 seats of Norway's parliament, the *[Storting](/wiki/Storting "Storting")*. The coalition government of the conservative [Conservative Party](/wiki/Conservative_Party_(Norway) "Conservative Party (Norway)") (Høyre) and the liberal [Venstre](/wiki/Liberal_Party_(Norway) "Liberal Party (Norway)"), led by Prime Minister [Johan Ludwig Mowinckel](/wiki/Johan_Ludwig_Mowinckel "Johan Ludwig Mowinckel")), maintained its slim majority, with 77 seats.

The first elections in Canada under the "[Indian Act](/wiki/Indian_Act "Indian Act")" were held for the [Six Nations Band of Indians Council](/wiki/Six_Nations_of_the_Grand_River_Elected_Council "Six Nations of the Grand River Elected Council"), a partially self-governing territory that served as a Canadian government forced replacement of the traditional [Six Nations Iroquois Confederacy](/wiki/Six_Nations_Iroquois_Confederacy "Six Nations Iroquois Confederacy") (the *Haudenosaunee*). The council had representatives for the [Mohawk](/wiki/Mohawk_people "Mohawk people"), [Oneida](/wiki/Oneida_people "Oneida people"), [Onondaga](/wiki/Onondaga_people "Onondaga people"), [Cayuga](/wiki/Cayuga_people "Cayuga people"), [Seneca](/wiki/Seneca_people "Seneca people") and [Tuscarora](/wiki/Tuscarora_people "Tuscarora people") people. The Council's first meeting was subsequently held the next day at the Iroquois capital in [Ohsweken, Ontario](/wiki/Ohsweken,_Ontario "Ohsweken, Ontario").
sources: "["The Six Nations' Election"](http://vitacollections.ca/sixnationsarchive/3217073/page/0)". Six Nations Public Library Digital Collections, ID: SNPL004217v00d. Six Nations Public Library.

content: The [German National People's Party](/wiki/German_National_People%27s_Party "German National People's Party") issued an official proclamation announcing itself in favour of restoring the monarchy and terminating the [Treaty of Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles") and the [Dawes Plan](/wiki/Dawes_Plan "Dawes Plan").
sources: [Seldes, George](/wiki/George_Seldes "George Seldes") (October 22, 1924). "Kaiserism Made Biggest German Election Issue". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 9.

content: [William Joyce](/wiki/William_Joyce "William Joyce"), a member of the [British Fascists](/wiki/British_Fascists "British Fascists"), was slashed with a razor by a communist hooligan while stewarding a meeting of Conservatives in North Lambeth, London. William Joyce would later gain notoriety as Nazi propagandist "[Lord Haw-Haw](/wiki/Lord_Haw-Haw "Lord Haw-Haw")" and would be hanged for treason in 1946.
sources: West, Rebecca (1964). [*The New Meaning of Treason*](https://archive.org/details/newmeaningoftrea00west). Viking Press. p. [25](https://archive.org/details/newmeaningoftrea00west/page/25).

content: Irish independence activist [Éamon de Valera](/wiki/%C3%89amon_de_Valera "Éamon de Valera") was arrested in [Newry](/wiki/Newry "Newry") as he arrived at a meeting of the [Sinn Féin](/wiki/Sinn_F%C3%A9in "Sinn Féin") party. He was charged with entering a prohibited area under the Civil Powers Act.
sources: Stewart, A.W. (October 25, 1924). "De Valera Put in Jail by Ulster to Halt Speech". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 11.

content: [Corneliu Codreanu](/wiki/Corneliu_Zelea_Codreanu "Corneliu Zelea Codreanu"), leader of Romania's fascist *[Iron Guard](/wiki/Iron_Guard "Iron Guard")* organization, assassinated Constantin Manciu, the police chief of the city of [Iași](/wiki/Ia%C8%99i "Iași"), and shot several other policemen. Codreanu would be acquitted on the grounds that he had acted in self-defense, despite invading the meeting and shooting Manciu from behind.

The British [Foreign Office](/wiki/Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Office "Foreign and Commonwealth Office") released the [Zinoviev letter](/wiki/Zinoviev_letter "Zinoviev letter"), allegedly a directive from Moscow addressed to the [Communist Party of Great Britain](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain "Communist Party of Great Britain") to increase labor unrest in the UK, and lodged a protest with the Soviet embassy.
sources: Steele, John (October 25, 1924). "Britain Tells Russia to Stop Red Propaganda". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 11.

content: Belgium signed the [Geneva Protocol](/wiki/Geneva_Protocol_(1924) "Geneva Protocol (1924)").
sources: "Belgium Signs League's World Peace Protocol". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 25, 1924. p. 11.

content: Crown Princes [Wilhem of Germany](/wiki/Wilhelm,_German_Crown_Prince "Wilhelm, German Crown Prince") and [Rupprecht of Bavaria](/wiki/Rupprecht,_Crown_Prince_of_Bavaria "Rupprecht, Crown Prince of Bavaria") reconciled after a six-year feud.
sources: "Crown Princes of Germany End Feud of 6 Years". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 25, 1924. p. 11.

content: The [Prince of Wales](/wiki/Edward_VIII "Edward VIII") ended his visit to the United States and Canada.
sources: "Prince of Wales". *[The Straits Times](/wiki/The_Straits_Times "The Straits Times")*. [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore "Singapore"): 9. October 25, 1924.

content: **Born:** [Mary Lee](/wiki/Mary_Lee_(actress) "Mary Lee (actress)") (stage name for Mary Lee Wooters), American singer and film actress for [Republic Pictures](/wiki/Republic_Pictures "Republic Pictures"), often in Westerns with [Gene Autry](/wiki/Gene_Autry "Gene Autry"); in [Centralia, Illinois](/wiki/Centralia,_Illinois "Centralia, Illinois")

The [Zinoviev letter](/wiki/Zinoviev_letter "Zinoviev letter"), a forgery received by the British Foreign Secretary and leaked by the British intelligence agency [MI6](/wiki/MI6 "MI6"), was published on the front page of the *[Daily Mail](/wiki/Daily_Mail "Daily Mail")* tabloid in [London](/wiki/London "London"), four days before the general election, and would become a major influence in the defeat of the Labour and Liberal parties in October 29 voting. The *Daily Mail* article commented that "The 'very secret' letter of instruction from Moscow discloses a great Bolshevist plot to paralyse the British Army and Navy and to plunge the country into civil war. The letter is addressed by the Bolshevists in Moscow to the Soviet Government's servants in Great Britain, the Communist Party, who in turn are the masters of Mr. Ramsay MacDonald's Government, which has signed a treaty with Moscow whereby the Soviet is to be guaranteed a 'loan' of millions of British money," and added, "A Copy of the document came into possession of 'The Daily Mail' and we felt it our duty to make it public, and we prented and sent copies to other London morning newspapers yesterday afternoon." The letter became the leading story in every British newspaper. Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald "Ramsay MacDonald") sent out instructions to all [Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)") candidates to drop their support for the Anglo-Soviet trade agreement, and the [Communist Party of Great Britain](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain "Communist Party of Great Britain") issued a statement in which it denied ever receiving the letter and declared it a forgery, but the damage done by the letter returned the Conservative Party to power.
sources: "Why the Foreign Office Acted. Knew That the Moscow Document Was To Be Published". *Staffordshire Evening Sentinel*. London. 25 October 1924. p. 2.
Steele, John (October 26, 1924). "Expose of Soviet Plot in Britain Dooms Russ Pact". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 21.

content: The world's leading [air conditioner](/wiki/Air_conditioner "Air conditioner") brand, [Daikin Industries](/wiki/Daikin_Industries "Daikin Industries"), was founded in [Osaka](/wiki/Osaka "Osaka"), [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan") (as name of predecessors for Osaka Metal Industry).[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]
Indian nationalist [Subhas Chandra Bose](/wiki/Subhas_Chandra_Bose "Subhas Chandra Bose") was arrested on trumped-up charges of plotting to overthrow the government.
sources: Jog, N.G. (1996). "An Indian Pilgrim". In Werth, Alexander (ed.). *Beacon Across Asia: Biography of Subhas Chandra Bose*. [Hyderabad](/wiki/Hyderabad "Hyderabad"): [Orient Longman Limited](/wiki/Orient_Blackswan "Orient Blackswan"). p. 17.

content: "[Trunko](/wiki/Trunko "Trunko")", a [cryptozoological](/wiki/Cryptozoology "Cryptozoology") unknown sea creature (a "[cryptid](/wiki/Cryptid "Cryptid")" was reportedly sighted at [Margate, South Africa](/wiki/Margate,_KwaZulu-Natal "Margate, KwaZulu-Natal"). Based on photographs of its [globster](/wiki/Globster "Globster") it is now believed to have been a whale carcass. The *Daily Mail* of London would break the story on December 27, 1924, with the headline "Fish Like A Polar Bear".
sources: Shuker, Karl (September 9, 2010). ["Trunko – Two More Photographs"](http://karlshuker.blogspot.ca/2010/09/trunko-two-more-photographs.html). *Shuker Nature*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: Poor ventilation in a chemical processing plant caused a mass accident in [Elizabeth, New Jersey](/wiki/Elizabeth,_New_Jersey "Elizabeth, New Jersey") that injured 40 employees of the [Bayway Refinery](/wiki/Bayway_Refinery "Bayway Refinery") of the [Standard Oil Company of New Jersey](/wiki/Standard_Oil_Company_of_New_Jersey "Standard Oil Company of New Jersey"), where leaded gasoline (called "ethyl" by the Standard Oil dealers) was produced using the additive [tetraethyllead](/wiki/Tetraethyllead "Tetraethyllead") (TEL). Ernest Oelgart became the first fatality after becoming paranoid following inhalation of fumes, and died later in the day. By the end of the week, 10 more workers were dead at Standard Oil plants.
sources: "Odd Gas Kills One, Makes Four Insane; Stricken at Work in Standard's Experiment Laboratory in Elizabeth, N.J.". *[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")*. October 27, 1924. p. 1.

Fuller, Gary (2019). [*The Invisible Killer: The Rising Global Threat of Air Pollution-and How We Can Fight Back*](https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Invisible_Killer/QbdzDwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=%22on+October+26,+1924%22&pg=PA53&printsec=frontcover). Melville House. p. 53-54.

content: The Soviet Union denied the authenticity of the [Zinoviev letter](/wiki/Zinoviev_letter "Zinoviev letter") (which purported to be a directive to British Communists to overthrow the government) and demanded an apology from Britain.
sources: "Russia Demands British Apology for Red Expose". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 27, 1924. p. 18.

content: France and the Soviet Union established diplomatic relations for the first time since the Communist government had replaced the Russian Empire in 1917. [Leonid Krasin](/wiki/Leonid_Krasin "Leonid Krasin") would become the [Soviet Ambassador to France](/wiki/List_of_ambassadors_of_Russia_to_France "List of ambassadors of Russia to France") on November 14, and Jean Herbette became France's envoy to Moscow.
sources: Wales, Henry (October 29, 1924). "France Extends Recognition to Soviet Russia". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 3.

content: Many prominent Spaniards opposed to the dictatorship of [Miguel Primo de Rivera](/wiki/Miguel_Primo_de_Rivera "Miguel Primo de Rivera") were arrested at a meeting in [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"). The writer [Pedro Sainz](/wiki/Pedro_Sainz_Rodr%C3%ADguez "Pedro Sainz Rodríguez") was among those imprisoned. General [Dámaso Berenguer](/wiki/D%C3%A1maso_Berenguer "Dámaso Berenguer") was present but not arrested at the time.
sources: "Spain Leaders Defy Dictator; Thrown into Jail". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 31, 1924. p. 5.

content: The British African protectorate of [Sierra Leone](/wiki/Sierra_Leone_Colony_and_Protectorate "Sierra Leone Colony and Protectorate") held its first elections for the native population. Voters were allowed to select three of the 22 members of the new [Legislative Council of Sierra Leone](/wiki/Legislative_Council_of_Sierra_Leone "Legislative Council of Sierra Leone"). The right to vote was limited to literate Africans who were at least 21 years old and had at least 10 pounds sterling of property. Out of 25,000 people, only 1,866 registered. [Ernest Beoku-Betts](/wiki/Ernest_Beoku-Betts "Ernest Beoku-Betts"), [Herbert Bankole-Bright](/wiki/Herbert_Bankole-Bright "Herbert Bankole-Bright") and Albert Tuboku-Metzger were elected. The other 19 Assembly members were made up of five appointed Africans and 14 British government officials.
sources: [Wyse, Akintola](/wiki/Akintola_J.G._Wyse "Akintola J.G. Wyse") (2003). *H. C. Bankole-Bright and Politics in Colonial Sierra Leone, 1919-1958*. Cambridge University Press. p. 57.

sources: "Death of French Actor: M. de Max's Career". *The Times*. London. 29 October 1924. p. 13.

content: [Voting took place in the UK](/wiki/1924_United_Kingdom_general_election "1924 United Kingdom general election") for all 615 seats of the [House of Commons](/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom "House of Commons of the United Kingdom") and was marked by a gain of 154 seats by the [Conservative Party](/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK) "Conservative Party (UK)") of former Prime Minister [Stanley Baldwin](/wiki/Stanley_Baldwin "Stanley Baldwin"), as well as a loss of 158 seats for the coalition of Prime Minister [Ramsey MacDonald](/wiki/Ramsey_MacDonald "Ramsey MacDonald")'s [Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)") and former Prime Minister [H. H. Asquith](/wiki/H._H._Asquith "H. H. Asquith")'s [Liberal Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_(UK) "Liberal Party (UK)"). With 308 seats needed for a majority, the Labour-Liberal coalition had a 349 to 258 control of Commons over the Conservatives. Baldwin's Tories had a 412 to 198 seat control after the voting.
sources: ["Election Statistics: UK 1918-2007"](https://web.archive.org/web/20140708134346/http://www.parliament.uk/documents/commons/lib/research/rp2008/rp08-012.pdf) (PDF). Archived from [the original](http://www.parliament.uk/documents/commons/lib/research/rp2008/rp08-012.pdf) (PDF) on 8 July 2014. Retrieved 23 May 2014.
Steele, John (October 30, 1924). "Britain Goes Conservative". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: **Born:** [Danielle Gouze Mitterrand](/wiki/Danielle_Mitterrand "Danielle Mitterrand"), *[Première dame de France](/wiki/List_of_spouses_or_partners_of_the_president_of_France "List of spouses or partners of the president of France")* from 1981 to 1995 as the wife of President [François Mitterrand](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand "François Mitterrand"); in [Verdun](/wiki/Verdun "Verdun"), [Meuse](/wiki/Meuse_(department) "Meuse (department)") *département* (d. 2011)
sources: ["Family tree of Danielle MITTERRAND"](https://en.geneastar.org/genealogy/gouzed/danielle-mitterrand). *[Geneanet](/wiki/Geneanet "Geneanet")*. Retrieved 2023-08-11.

Eight deputies of the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State")'s parliament, the [Dáil Éireann](/wiki/D%C3%A1il_%C3%89ireann "Dáil Éireann")— [Francis Cahill](/wiki/Francis_Cahill "Francis Cahill"), [Thomas Carter](/wiki/Thomas_Carter_(TD) "Thomas Carter (TD)"), [Henry Finlay](/wiki/Henry_Finlay "Henry Finlay"), [Seán Gibbons](/wiki/Se%C3%A1n_Gibbons "Seán Gibbons"), [Alexander McCabe](/wiki/Alexander_McCabe "Alexander McCabe"), [Daniel McCarthy](/wiki/Daniel_McCarthy_(politician) "Daniel McCarthy (politician)"), [Seán McGarry](/wiki/Se%C3%A1n_McGarry "Seán McGarry") and [Seán Milroy](/wiki/Se%C3%A1n_Milroy "Seán Milroy")— resigned after the government response in the [Irish Army Mutiny](/wiki/Irish_Army_Mutiny "Irish Army Mutiny").
sources: ["Resignation of Deputies – Dáil Éireann (4th Dáil) – Vol. 9 No. 6"](https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/debates/debate/dail/1924-10-30/16/). *Houses of the Oireachtas*. 30 October 1924. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20220722181551/https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/debates/debate/dail/1924-10-30/16/) from the original on 22 July 2022. Retrieved 22 July 2022.

content: Seven days after overthrowing China's President [Cao Kun](/wiki/Cao_Kun "Cao Kun") in the [Beijing Coup](/wiki/Beijing_Coup "Beijing Coup"), Chinese warlord [Feng Yuxiang](/wiki/Feng_Yuxiang "Feng Yuxiang") broke with the [Zhili clique](/wiki/Zhili_clique "Zhili clique") and allied his forces with the [Fengtian clique](/wiki/Fengtian_clique "Fengtian clique") led by [Zhang Zuolin](/wiki/Zhang_Zuolin "Zhang Zuolin"), inviting Zhang to form a new, pro-Japanese, government.
sources: Bruce A. Elleman (2005). [*Modern Chinese Warfare, 1795-1989*](https://books.google.com/books?id=j1aGAgAAQBAJ). Routledge. pp. 164–165. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [1134610092](/wiki/Special:BookSources/1134610092 "Special:BookSources/1134610092").

content: Chemical engineer [Thomas Midgley Jr.](/wiki/Thomas_Midgley_Jr. "Thomas Midgley Jr.") of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey (later [Exxon](/wiki/Exxon "Exxon")) participated in a [press conference](/wiki/Press_conference "Press conference") to demonstrate the apparent safety of the gasoline additive [tetraethyllead](/wiki/Tetraethyllead "Tetraethyllead") (TEL). Midgley poured the TEL over his hands, placed a bottle of it under his nose, and inhaled its [vapor](/wiki/Vapor "Vapor") for 60 seconds, declaring that he could do this every day without succumbing to [any problems](/wiki/Lead_poisoning "Lead poisoning"). Despite the demonstration, the U.S. state of New Jersey closed the [Bayway Refinery](/wiki/Bayway_Refinery "Bayway Refinery"), where five workers had died and 35 others were seriously injured from lead poisoning by TEL fumes.
sources: Kitman, Jamie Lincoln (2000-03-02). ["The Secret History of Lead"](https://www.thenation.com/article/archive/secret-history-lead/). [ISSN](/wiki/ISSN_(identifier) "ISSN (identifier)") [0027-8378](https://www.worldcat.org/issn/0027-8378). Retrieved 2022-04-27.

Markowitz, Gerald E. (2002). [*Deceit and denial the deadly politics of industrial pollution*](http://worldcat.org/oclc/492221280). University of California Press. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [0-520-21749-7](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-520-21749-7 "Special:BookSources/0-520-21749-7"). [OCLC](/wiki/OCLC_(identifier) "OCLC (identifier)") [492221280](https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/492221280).

content: [Henry Ford](/wiki/Henry_Ford "Henry Ford") endorsed [Calvin Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge") for re-election, calling him "short on promises and long on action."
sources: "Ford Tells It: Why He's All For Coolidge". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. October 31, 1924. p. 1.

content: **Died:** [Stina Quint](/wiki/Stina_Quint "Stina Quint"), 65, Swedish publisher and founder of the children's magazine *[Kamratposten](/wiki/Kamratposten "Kamratposten")*
sources: Svensson, Sonja. ["Kristina (Stina) Quint"](https://sok.riksarkivet.se/Sbl/Presentation.aspx?id=7463). *[Svenskt biografiskt lexikon](/wiki/Svenskt_biografiskt_lexikon "Svenskt biografiskt lexikon")* (in Swedish). Retrieved 10 June 2021.

content: The government of [Miguel Primo de Rivera](/wiki/Miguel_Primo_de_Rivera "Miguel Primo de Rivera") had Spain's highest general, [Dámaso Berenguer](/wiki/D%C3%A1maso_Berenguer "Dámaso Berenguer"), sentenced to six months' imprisonment for insubordination. All others present at the meeting of October 28 were condemned to [solitary confinement](/wiki/Solitary_confinement "Solitary confinement") for an indefinite period without trial.
sources: "Spain's Highest General Sent to Prison as a Rebel". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. November 1, 1924. p. 1.

content: The [Japan Swimming Federation](/wiki/Japan_Swimming_Federation "Japan Swimming Federation") was founded.
The Ukraine sports club [Dynamo](/wiki/Dynamo_(Ukraine) "Dynamo (Ukraine)") was founded.
